question_details.title: Will the FDA approve a seasonal influenza vaccine for the 2025-2026 flu season before October 1, 2025?
question_details.description:
This question is synced with an identical question on Metaculus. The original question opened on 2025-03-04 21:38:00 and can be found [here](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/35582). This question will resolve to the same value as the synced question. The original question's background info at this time is below. 

On February 26, 2025, the FDA unexpectedly canceled its Vaccines and Related Biological Products Advisory Committee (VRBPAC) meeting that was scheduled for March 2025. This meeting is typically held annually to select the influenza virus strains to be included in the upcoming season's flu vaccines for the United States.

The FDA has maintained an uninterrupted annual approval process for seasonal influenza vaccines since 1973. Each year, the FDA follows a consistent timeline for approving updated flu vaccine formulations based on recommendations about which influenza strains are likely to circulate during the upcoming flu season. The strain selection process typically occurs in spring to give vaccine manufacturers sufficient time to produce shots for fall distribution.

The cancellation coincides with other significant changes in U.S. public health policy:

* In January 2025, President Donald Trump issued an executive order to begin withdrawing the U.S. from the World Health Organization (WHO)
* Federal health officials were subsequently ordered to stop communicating with the WHO
* A CDC vaccine advisory committee meeting was also recently postponed

`{"format":"metac_closes_in_period","info":{"post_id":35582,"question_id":35030}}`
question_details.fine_print:
For resolution purposes, a "seasonal influenza vaccine" refers to any vaccine formulation specifically developed for the 2025-2026 influenza season. This excludes previously approved vaccines that might be used off-label or as substitutes in the absence of a newly formulated vaccine.

If the FDA approves a multi-year influenza vaccine that explicitly covers the 2025-2026 season, this will count as a **YES** resolution.

Here are the relevant news articles:

**Florida’s School Vaccine Requirement Change Will Not Take Effect Until December**
Florida’s Department of Health announced that a modification to school vaccination requirements will not take effect until at least 90 days after its introduction on September 3 2025, effectively delaying implementation until December. The change will reduce mandatory vaccines to varicella, hepatitis B, influenza Hib, and pneumococcal diseases, while keeping polio, measles, diphtheria, pertussis, mumps, and tetanus. The decision places responsibility on parents, as stated by state health secretary Joseph Ladapo: 'Si quieren, Dios los bendiga, pueden poner todas las que deseen. Y si no, los padres deben tener la capacidad y el poder de decidir qué entra en el cuerpo de sus hijos. Es así de simple'. The move follows a rise in vaccine‑preventable diseases: measles has reached its worst U.S. outbreak in over 30 years with more than 1,400 confirmed cases and three deaths, mainly in Texas; pertussis has caused the deaths of at least two babies in Louisiana and a five‑year‑old in Washington, with more than 19,000 reported cases as of August 23, up nearly 2,000 from the same date last year, according to CDC preliminary data. The World Health Organization reports that vaccines have saved at least 154 million lives worldwide in the past 50 years. Florida currently allows religious exemptions. The state legislature will not reconvene until January 2026, with committees meeting in October, meaning the current vaccination schedule will remain in force for the rest of the year.

**Despite Policy Confusion, Vaccines for Flu, COVID Still Strongly Recommended**
Michigan Medicine experts explain that flu, RSV, and COVID vaccines remain essential for preventing severe disease and death. Pamela Rockwell, D.O., notes that immunization rates are falling, citing a recent measles outbreak and that 14 Michigan children died of the flu last year, most unvaccinated. Adam Lauring, M.D., Ph.D., confirms that the science of vaccine benefit hasn't changed. He states the 2025‑2026 flu vaccine is updated and should be available soon; for most people it can be taken anytime, but if not high‑risk, October is acceptable. Lauring also describes FluMist, an inhaled live‑attenuated vaccine approved for home use in ages 2‑49, noting it can cause mild sniffles but does not give flu. RSV vaccine recommendations target people over 75, those 50‑74 with chronic conditions, and pregnant women between 32‑36 weeks; a monoclonal antibody, nirsevimab, protects infants ≤8 months. CDC data for the 2024‑2025 RSV season show 190,000‑350,000 hospitalizations and 10,000‑23,000 deaths. Regarding COVID, Rockwell says the recommendation that people 6 months and older are eligible remains, but policy changes may limit access: the FDA ended emergency use for Pfizer in kids under 5, leaving Moderna as the only option; the FDA now recommends COVID vaccines only for those 65+ or at high risk, listing conditions such as heart disease, lung disease, cancer, obesity, chronic kidney disease, liver disease, diabetes, depression, disabilities, physical inactivity, pregnancy, etc. She warns that insurance coverage could be jeopardized and that many patients declined the vaccine when offered.

**Butantan’s Race to Produce 80 Million Flu Vaccine Doses Before Next Winter**
The article explains how the Instituto Butantan in São Paulo is operating a "war‑like" effort to produce 80 million doses of the seasonal influenza vaccine before the upcoming winter. The vaccine relies on an inactivated virus that must be updated each year to match the circulating strain. According to Priscila Comone, manager of the Influenza Virus Banks (PBI), "Quando a Organização Mundial da Saúde [OMS] anuncia a necessidade de atualização do imunizante, precisamos trazer os novos vírus do exterior de maneira prioritária, uma vez que seu rápido recebimento é essencial para garantir que o produto seja fabricado a tempo e aplicado na população‑alvo antes da chegada do inverno, período crítico da doença." The update is traditionally announced on the last Friday of September; Butantan’s nine areas and 15 professionals coordinate the import of strains from the United States, United Kingdom, China, Japan and Australia. The vaccine contains three strains—two A subtypes (H1N1 and H3N2) and one B subtype that infects only humans. Historically, only one of these strains changes annually.

A critical logistical challenge is the supply of eggs, the medium in which the virus is amplified. More than 500 000 eggs are required each day for five months, and they must come from specially raised, pathogen‑free chickens. Two weeks before the WHO announcement, Butantan schedules two deliveries: 500 000 eggs from certified Brazilian farms and 1 700 eggs imported from the United States, classified as Specific Pathogen Free. These eggs are used to produce a 2 ml "seed bank" of the imported strain. If only one strain changes, the factory can continue producing the two unchanged monovalent vaccines while expediting the new strain’s import. The coordinated September operation allows the first batches to be ready in March–April of the following year, enabling the federal government to distribute the doses nationwide before the June winter onset.

Key metrics: 80 million doses planned; 500 000 eggs/day for five months; 1 700 imported eggs; three vaccine strains; production ready by March–April; distribution before June.

**Public Flu Vaccine Rollout on Oct 1; CDC Switches to Trivalent Vaccine for This Year**
The Taiwan Centers for Disease Control (CDC) announced that the public‑funded influenza vaccination campaign will begin on 1 October.  In a shift from the previous four‑valent formulation, the CDC will procure a trivalent vaccine for the 2024 season.  The change follows a World Health Organization (WHO) recommendation that, since March 2020, no natural B‑type Yamagata strain has been detected worldwide, and that the strain should be removed from vaccine compositions.  CDC Deputy Director Tseng Shih‑hui explained that the decision was made after the 24 January 2024 advisory meeting of the Ministry of Health and Welfare’s Infectious Disease Prevention and Control Advisory Committee.  The agency will purchase 6 864 910 trivalent doses, of which 6 479 080 are earmarked for the 114‑year influenza vaccination program, 185 830 for central and local procurement, and an additional 200 000 doses may be ordered to meet demand.  The procurement cost is about 1.57 billion New Taiwan dollars.  Five manufacturers—Guangong, GlaxoSmithKline, Taiwan Oriental, Sanofi, and High‑End Vaccine—will supply the vaccine.  Children from elementary to high school, vocational, and junior college first‑through‑third‑year students will receive the vaccine on campus to reduce travel for parents.  The CDC is also improving the “Vaccination Administration Electronic System (NIAS)” so parents can sign consent online via a QR code or link, or use paper forms if preferred.  Tseng noted that the switch to a trivalent vaccine aligns Taiwan with advanced countries and follows WHO guidance.

**Prevention and Control of Seasonal Influenza...**
CDC’s 2025‑26 influenza vaccine recommendations specify that all U.S. vaccines will be trivalent, containing the following strains: an H1N1pdm09‑like virus derived from A/Victoria/4897/2022 (egg‑based) or A/Wisconsin/67/2022 (cell‑culture or recombinant); an H3N2‑like virus derived from A/Croatia/10136RV/2023 (egg‑based) or A/District of Columbia/27/2023 (cell‑culture or recombinant); and an influenza B Victoria‑lineage virus derived from B/Austria/1359417/2021. This updates the H3N2 component from the 2024‑25 season. Routine annual vaccination is recommended for all persons ≥6 months without contraindication. The CDC advises that most people receive one dose in September or October, but vaccination can continue after October as long as viruses circulate and vaccine is available. "Vaccination during July and August is not recommended for most groups because of potential waning of vaccine‑induced immunity during the influenza season." July and August vaccination is generally discouraged except for specific groups: older adults (≥65 years) and pregnant women in the first or second trimester should avoid July/August unless later vaccination is uncertain; children who need two doses should start as early as possible, even in July/August, to allow a second dose ≥4 weeks later; pregnant women in the third trimester may be vaccinated in July/August because it protects infants. Vaccine selection guidelines state that children ≤18 years, pregnant women, and all adults should receive single‑dose formulations free of thimerosal. Adults ≥65 years are preferentially recommended to receive a high‑dose or adjuvanted vaccine (HD‑IIV3, RIV3, or aIIV3). LAIV3 is not recommended for pregnancy, immunocompromised persons, or those with certain medical conditions, and is contraindicated for ages <2 or >49 years. Contraindications include a history of severe allergic reaction to any vaccine component; egg allergy is a labeled contraindication for egg‑based IIV3s and LAIV3, but the CDC recommends that all persons with egg allergy receive an appropriate influenza vaccine. The guidance also details dosing schedules for children 6 months–8 years who may need one or two doses depending on prior vaccination history, and specifies intramuscular administration volumes (0.5 mL for most, 0.25 mL for certain Afluria doses).
